; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 09:52:01 +0800 Ford and United Auto Workers’ union negotiators reach potential new dealhttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/oct/25/ford-united-auto-workers-union-deal-strike-general-motors-stellantis
;;2023-10-26T00:30:47Z;
;
;;2023 年 10 月 7 日，UAW 主席 Shawn Fain 在 UAW Local 551 举行罢工工人集会后。
;

;几家新闻媒体周三报道称，福特汽车公司和美国汽车工人联合会 (UAW) 的谈判代表已达成一项劳工协议，有待工会领导层批准。

;

;该协议将是第一个和解协议针对福特、通用汽车和 Stellantis 的罢工。

;
;

;;相关：;;UAW 扩大对通用汽车的罢工范围，在德克萨斯州装配厂举行罢工;

;
;

;超过 45,000 名工会成员在该工厂工作底特律三大汽车制造商已加入自 9 月 15 日开始的罢工。

;

;其中一位消息人士称，该交易预计将在合同期内提高 25% 的工资，其中包括开始时的 11%。包括复利和生活费用在内，根据暂定协议，工人们将获得超过30%的补贴。据报道，该协议还将减少新工人达到最高工资所需的时间，从八年缩短到三年。

;

;如果达成一致，工会协议将是几项;过去几个月，美国工会在达成两位数加薪协议后取得了重大胜利;包裹巨头 UPS、好莱坞作家和 Kaiser Permanente 的卫生工作者。

;

;UAW 主席 Shawn Fain 尚未发表声明确认协议，工会领导人可能需要几天时间才能审查细节。

; <该协议能否获得批准将取决于 Fain 和 UAW 领导人的决定，但目前尚不确定。本月早些时候，麦克卡车的 UAW 工人拒绝了费恩同意的拟议合同。现在名为 Stellantis 的公司的 UAW 工人拒绝了 2015 年 UAW 领导人批准的一项提议。

;

;UAW 最近的举动是罢工各公司最赚钱的工厂 - 通用汽车位于德克萨斯州阿灵顿的装配厂；以及位于德克萨斯州阿灵顿的通用汽车组装厂。福特位于肯塔基州的卡车重型皮卡工厂；安德森经济集团本周表示，UAW 罢工造成的总经济损失已达 93 亿美元。

;

;如果合同是得到福特-UAW工人的批准，它将为通用汽车和Stellantis设定谈判标准，并于2028年到期。

;

;“这为接下来的两份合同奠定了基础，它们应该很快就会生效因为这三者之间的差距很小，”AutoForecast Solutions 全球车辆预测副总裁 Sam Fiorani 说道。

;

;“到目前为止，罢工对每个人来说都是痛苦的，并且知道什么“签署合同所需的时间应该会让他们更快地坐到谈判桌上。”他说。

;

;这三家公司没有立即发表评论。

;

;工会发起了一场不寻常的运动同时针对底特律三大汽车制造商举行罢工，要求加薪 40%，包括立即加薪 20%、改善福利以及根据工会协议涵盖电动汽车电池厂工人。

;

;汽车制造商辩称， UAW的要求将大幅提高成本，并阻碍他们的电动汽车雄心，使他们与未加入工会的特斯拉和丰田等外国品牌相比处于劣势。

;

; UAW 在历史上曾进行过大规模罢工，并利用扩大停工范围的缓刑作为鼓励，让两家公司相互对立。

;

;CNBC 早些时候报道了这项暂定协议。

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 08:52:01 +0800 Aukus will ‘get done’ despite jitters in Congress, Biden tells Albanese at White House meetinghttps://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2023/oct/26/aukus-will-get-done-despite-jitters-in-congress-biden-tells-albanese-at-white-house-meeting
;;2023-10-25T19:40:32Z;
;
;;安东尼·艾博尼斯和乔·拜登走进玫瑰园，参加白宫新闻发布会
;

;乔·拜登淡化了;国会的不安情绪; 就奥库斯核动力潜艇交易进行了讨论，并透露他向习近平保证，相关国家无意“包围中国”。

;

;美国总统欢迎澳大利亚总理安东尼·阿尔巴内斯 (Anthony Albanese) ，到白宫并坚称他“相信我们能够为 Aukus 筹集到资金，因为这绝对符合我们的利益”。

;

;“所以问题不是是否，而是何时美国时间周三（澳大利亚时间周四），拜登在玫瑰园与阿尔巴尼斯举行联合新闻发布会时说道。

;

;拜登还转述了他此前与中国国家主席就奥库斯安全伙伴关系进行的对话，澳大利亚、美国和英国已承诺在先进防御能力方面进行合作。

;

;“当我被问及我们何时达成这项协议时，习近平问我，我们是否只是想包围中国？”拜登说道，“我说，不，我们不是包围中国。我们只是确保海上航线保持开放，不能单方面改变国际空域、水域、太空等方面的道路规则。”

;

;拜登和阿尔巴尼斯在白宫进行了广泛的会谈后向记者发表了讲话。他们; ;承诺在包括太空在内的众多领域进行合作，该协议为从澳大利亚发射美国商业航天器铺平了道路。

;

;重点强调与太平洋公司的合作各国在该地区的影响力竞争日益激烈。

;
;

;;相关：;;Aukus 应该保证我们的安全 - 那么为什么会有这种下沉的感觉呢？ |菲奥娜·卡塔斯卡斯;

;
;

;领导人宣布美国和澳大利亚计划“共同资助基里巴斯的关键海事基础设施项目，包括修复塔拉瓦的坎顿码头和查理码头” 。他们还将通过银行服务和海底电缆协助太平洋国家。

;

;气候危机是谈判的重要组成部分，计划在电池供应链上进行合作，“探索深化两国的制造能力”拜登和阿尔巴尼斯在联合声明中承认，“实现《巴黎协定》的目标需要快速部署清洁能源和脱碳技术，并提高电气化程度”。这是阿尔巴内塞自 2022 年 5 月大选以来第九次与拜登会面，尽管之前的会面大多是在国际活动间隙进行的。

;

;周二晚上，拜登和第一夫人吉尔·拜登欢迎阿尔巴尼斯和他的伴侣朱迪·海顿来到白宫参加私人晚宴，但主要的外交会谈于周三举行。

;

;这一天以在白宫南草坪上的欢迎仪式开始，然后两位领导人在椭圆形办公室举行正式会议。

;

;拜登在会议开始时“再次因未能与会面而道歉”。 “我五月访问澳大利亚”，当时悉尼四方峰会因美国债务上限谈判而被取消。

;

;“这里的情况有点混乱，需要回家，”拜登告诉阿尔巴内斯。

;

;拜登还在椭圆形办公室告诉阿尔巴内斯：“几年前，习近平问我为什么要为你们的国家（澳大利亚）如此努力地工作。我说，因为我们是太平洋国家……我们将保持这种状态。”

;

;阿尔巴尼斯将在美国时间周三晚些时候（美国东部夏令时间周四上午晚些时候）举行国宴。

;

;拜登将与澳大利亚的关系描述为“牢固”并且正在变得“更加牢固”，而阿尔巴内塞则表示，该联盟是基于“对自由和民主的信念、对机会的信念、建立繁荣和繁荣国家的决心”。更和平的世界”。

;

;然而，七个月后，阿尔巴尼斯在圣地亚哥与拜登和英国首相里希·苏纳克一起;宣布 Aukus 计划;，还有;他们需要国会批准的不确定性;成功。

;

;奥库斯将要求对美国出口管制体系进行改革。国会还需要授权在 2030 年代向澳大利亚出售至少三艘弗吉尼亚级潜艇，但一些共和党人担心这将以牺牲美国自身的需求为代价。澳大利亚制造的核动力潜艇将于 2040 年代开始服役。

;

;周三，拜登与阿尔巴尼斯站在一起，敦促国会“今年通过我们的奥库斯立法”。

;

;阿尔巴尼斯淡化了对该协议的担忧，称他认为美国“是一个非常可靠的合作伙伴”。

;

;“我认为我与总统的关系是我所拥有的关系中首屈一指的。就这一点而言，在世界各地，甚至在国内，”阿尔巴内斯说。

;

;总理表示，他“对我与民主党人和共和党人的讨论非常有信心，认为得到了非常广泛的支持”阿尔巴内斯表示，他期待在;下个月访问中国;，称此类会谈对于建立理解和缓解紧张局势非常重要

;

;当被问及澳大利亚是否可以信任中国时，拜登表示“信任但要核实”很重要。

;

;拜登和阿尔巴尼斯还讨论了;以色列与哈马斯冲突;。他们在联合声明中表示，哈马斯对以色列的袭击“没有任何道理，没有合法性，必须受到普遍谴责”。

;
;

;;相关：;;唐纳德·特朗普称亿万富翁安东尼·普拉特为“来自澳大利亚的红发怪人”，因为他否认讨论潜艇;

;
;

;同时承诺“支持以色列保卫自己和人民免受此类暴行”两位领导人还呼吁“各方采取符合国际法原则的行动，并将保护平民作为首要任务”。

;

;“我们对加沙的人道主义局势感到关切，并呼吁各方拜登和阿尔巴尼斯表示：“我们继续支持巴勒斯坦建立自己国家的愿望，并认为两国解决方案是最好的途径实现持久和平。”

;

;阿尔巴内斯宣布澳大利亚将为加沙平民额外提供 1500 万美元的人道主义援助。

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 08:52:01 +0800 David Kirke, performer of world’s first modern-day bungee jump, dies aged 78https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/oct/25/david-kirke-who-performed-worlds-first-ever-modern-day-bungee-jump-dies-aged-78
;;2023-10-25T22:16:55Z;
;
;;David Kirke 多年后接受 Bridge 采访
;

;表演世界上第一个现代表演的人 -一天，戴着大礼帽、穿着燕尾服、手里拿着一瓶香槟的蹦极者去世，享年 78 岁。

;

;牛津大学危险运动俱乐部的先驱之一戴维·柯克 (David Kirke) 从克利夫顿悬架上跳下1979 年 4 月 1 日的大桥。

;

;另外三名朋友在完成悬挂式滑翔之旅后，从布里斯托尔这座由松紧绳连接的 245 英尺（76m）桥上跳了下来。四人被朋友拖了回来，并因扰乱治安被警方​​逮捕，每人被罚款 100 英镑。

;

;柯克受到瓦努阿图陆地跳水仪式的启发而进行了蹦极活动。南太平洋。

;

;他的家人形容他是“一个自由的精神”。 “他拥有而且需要钢铁般的体质，从前线领导，前往许多人不敢涉足的地方。他们补充道，我们会非常怀念他。

;

;柯克的家人告诉 BBC，他“生性善良、慷慨”，“在 40 多个国家交了朋友，享受了一杯葡萄酒，而且永远不会有这样的经历”。改变了他的生活。

; ;

;1979 年的特技表演导致吊桥蹦极被章程禁止后，危险运动项目俱乐部通过从旧金山金门大桥和科罗拉多州皇家峡谷吊桥等建筑物进行跳伞，在全球范围内传播了这一概念。到 1982 年，俱乐部成员开始从移动式起重机和热气球上跳下。

;

;柯克说，从伊桑巴德·金德姆·布鲁内尔 (Isambard Kingdom Brunel) 拥有 150 年历史的建筑上跳下是一个“近乎幸福的时刻”。不过，他说“真正的回报”是蹦极让他从未见过的人感到高兴，并且他“给了他们乐趣”。

;

;柯克在 2000 年从同一座桥上蹦极，庆祝这项运动成立 21 周年。

;

;危险运动俱乐部的最初成员是 Chris Baker、Kirke 和 Ed Hulton。受到他们工作的启发，AJ Hackett 从 1988 年开始发展这项运动，他的祖国新西兰成为这项运动的非官方发源地。

;

;柯克继续尝试发展微光和其他极限运动。 1986 年，他被绑在袋鼠形状的氦气球簇上飞越英吉利海峡，这导致他因无飞行员执照飞行而被起诉。

;

;他曾被从美国悬崖上的飞机发射器发射。爱尔兰，他的脊椎三处骨折。

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 06:52:02 +0800 Meta earnings report reveals most profitable quarter in yearshttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/oct/25/meta-earnings-report-profitable-quarter-facebook
;;2023-10-25T21:12:34Z;
;
;;在柏林 Meta 公司办公室举行的发布会上，参观者站在 Meta 徽标前
;

;Meta 在其第三季度收益报告中飙升，超出了分析师的预期，巩固了投资者的信心，相信这家之前陷入困境的科技公司在经历了几年的动荡之后已经摆脱了困境。

;

;该公司报告了第三季度的收入341.5 亿美元，超出预期的 335.6 亿美元，同比增长 23%。股价在盘后交易中上涨了 10% 以上，Meta 多年来一直在波动，试图重组其业务模式并扩展到其建立帝国的社交媒体产品之外，结果提振了投资者的信心。

; < p>;该报告标志着 Meta 多年来利润最高的季度，是在前两个季度报告之后发布的 ;发布了好于预期的结果;。就在一天前，拥有 Instagram、Facebook 和 WhatsApp 的 Meta 遭到了;周二，33 个州的总检察长提起大规模诉讼;。各州正在起诉该公司对年轻用户的影响，指控其社交媒体平台的成瘾性损害了心理健康。

;

;这起诉讼只是 Meta 面临的最新阻力，因为该公司在更广泛的经济低迷时期，其核心广告业务陷入困境，并努力留住跳槽到 TikTok 等新平台的用户。投资者还对 Meta 应对苹果 2021 年实施的大规模隐私变更影响的能力表示持续担忧，该变更限制了 Meta 可以收集的用户数据量，从而威胁到了 Meta 的核心广告业务。

;

;Meta 已试图通过摆脱社交媒体，将数十亿美元的资金投入虚拟现实项目元宇宙来应对这些持续的斗争。但该领域已经损失了数十亿美元，在马克·扎克伯格和其他高管希望安抚日益担忧的投资者之际，盈利之路并不明朗。

;

;与科技领域的许多公司一样，Meta 也争先恐后地进军蓬勃发展的人工智能领域。情报趋势，在最近的财报中重点关注人工智能工具。 Investing.com 高级分析师杰西·科恩 (Jesse Cohen) 表示，Meta 的强劲报告表明这些努力正在取得回报。 >;，他补充说，对于这家科技公司来说，这是“一个井喷的季度”。

;

;“Meta 不仅每股收益和收入都超出了预期，而且大幅超出了预期，因为社交媒体公司受益于其不断扩大的用户群、越来越多的卷轴采用和新的人工智能计划，”他说。

;

;该公司在第四季度的指导中表示，预计收入将强劲，这意味着在经历了一段以大规模裁员为特征的波动期后，Meta 可能会趋于稳定;以大规模裁员为特征的;并激发投资者信心。

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 05:52:01 +0800 Clarence Thomas failed to fully repay $267,000 loan for luxury RV, inquiry findshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/oct/25/clarence-thomas-anthony-welters-luxury-rv-loan-forgiven

;;2020 年 10 月艾米·科尼·巴雷特 (Amy Coney Barrett) 宣誓就职时，克拉伦斯·托马斯 (Clarence Thomas) 与唐纳德·特朗普 (Donald Trump) 在一起。

;参议院委员会称，美国最高法院法官克拉伦斯·托马斯未能偿还借款超过 267,000 美元购买豪华房车的“甜心交易”的大部分（或可能全部）;发现;。

;

;;相关：;;法官因违反禁言令而对特朗普罚款 10,000 美元，并表示他作为证人“不可信”;

;
;

;最初的 RV 故事是在大量报道中出现的，< a href="https://www.propublica.org/">;ProPublica; 发布的许多内容，涉及托马斯 (Thomas) 涉嫌道德上的失误。托马斯是 1991 年任命的保守派人士，他未能申报 ;右翼捐助者;。托马斯否认有不当行为，但这些报道，特别是有关巨额捐助者哈伦·克劳的报道，以及其他法官未申报的礼物和意外之财的故事，引发了人们对保守派主导的法院公正性的质疑，并呼吁道德改革.

;

;参议院民主党人提出了这样的改革，但由于共和党的反对，成功的机会很小。首席大法官约翰·罗伯茨 (John Roberts) 拒绝出庭作证。

;

;最高法院法官名义上与所有联邦法官一样遵守相同的道德规则，但实际上却实行自我管理。

;

;在以豪华房车为例 - 普雷沃斯特马拉松 Le Mirage XL - Welters 在 1999 年借给托马斯钱。这位商人 ;告诉《泰晤士报》;：“我借给了朋友钱，因为我还有其他朋友和家人。我们都站在这个等式的一边。”

;

;但周三，参议院财政委员会表示，它现在看到的文件显示年利率为 7.5%，但没有支付义务扣除本金后，每年只需支付 20,042 美元的利息。该委员会还;表示;它看到了托马斯的一份承诺遵守条款的说明。

;

;“委员会工作人员审查的文件均未表明托马斯向 Welters 支付的款项超过了贷款年利息，”专家组表示。

;

;正如 < a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/25/us/politics/clarence-thomas-rv-loan-senate-inquiry.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare" >;《泰晤士报》;，2004 年贷款到期时，韦尔特斯批准了 10 年的延期，“尽管托马斯大法官在前一年为他的自传预收了 150 万美元预付款中的 50 万美元，根据他的财务报告披露。然后，根据委员会的;报告，在 2008 年底，韦尔特斯先生干脆免除了贷款余额< /a>;。”

;

;委员会表示，同期的一份报告显示，韦尔特斯表示，托马斯的“仅利息”付款超过了房车的价值。但证据并没有支持这一说法，韦尔特斯只向调查人员提供了一份托马斯开具的已注销支票的副本，其中包含年利息金额。

;

;哈默斯利告诉《泰晤士报》：“没有一家银行的行为符合商业合理性，一开始就会以公平的方式提供这笔贷款。银行不会只是说，‘哦，天啊，你已经支付了很多利息 - 我们很好，不需要偿还你实际欠下的钱。’”

;

;Hamersley 还表示美国国税局会将任何此类礼物视为应税收入。

;

;参议院财务委员会民主党主席罗恩·怀登 (Ron Wyden)，;说;：“现在我们知道托马斯大法官已免除了高达 267,230 美元的债务，并且从未在他的道德表格上报告过这一情况。

;

;“普通美国人不会这样做让富有的朋友免除巨额债务……托马斯法官应该准确告知委员会免除了多少债务，以及他是否在纳税申报表上正确报告了贷款免除情况并缴纳了所有所欠税款。”

;

;呼吁托马斯辞职或被弹劾和免职的情况激增。这种结果仍然不太可能出现，但周三，监管机构 Accountable.US 总裁卡罗琳·西科内 (Caroline Ciccone) 表示，托马斯的股价已达到“新低”，法官“在最高法院一切如常，同时规避所有道德标准以谋取利益”。他富有的朋友 - 高达数十万美元。

;

;“托马斯法官显然将他在我们国家最高法院的职位视为一个提升自己生活方式的机会，而且不会产生任何后果。越来越清楚的是，他不适合在我们的高等法院任职。托马斯法官必须辞职。”

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 05:22:01 +0800 Republican Mike Johnson elected House speaker after weeks of chaoshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/oct/25/mike-johnson-republican-house-speaker-vote

;
;;迈克·约翰逊 10 月 25 日在美国国会大厦投票期间。
;

;共和党 ;路易斯安那州的迈克·约翰逊;当选议长周三，众议院通过党派路线投票赢得了最高职位，结束了持续三周多的僵局。

;

;在众议院投票中，约翰逊赢得了所有 220 名共和党人的支持投票，所有 209 名出席的民主党人都投票给了他们的领导人、纽约州的哈基姆·杰弗里斯 (Hakeem Jeffries)。由于四次缺席众议院，约翰逊需要 215 票才能成为议长。

;

;约翰逊作为第 56 任众议院议长发表首次演讲，誓言要“重建和恢复”美国人民的信任，他承认，最近几周的混乱已经损害了这一点。

;

;“在这个巨大的危机时刻，我们有责任像前几代伟大领导人一样共同努力，应对这些巨大的挑战和解决这些重大问题，”约翰逊说。

;

;“我们希望世界各地的盟友知道，这个立法者团体正在再次向我们的工作地点汇报。让世界各地自由的敌人大声而清晰地听到我们的声音：人民众议院已恢复正常运转。”

;

;在祝贺约翰逊获胜的声明中，乔·拜登承诺“与[众议院共和党人]合作”拜登表示，“尽管我们在重要问题上存在真正的分歧，但我们应该共同努力，尽可能找到共同点。” “现在是我们所有人采取负责任行动的时候，并将美国人民的利益和美国家庭的日常优先事项置于任何党派之争之上。”

;

;约翰逊周二赢得了众议院共和党议长提名晚上，就在明尼苏达州多数党党鞭汤姆·埃默 (Tom Emmer) 当选后几个小时;经过三轮投票;击败佛罗里达州的拜伦·唐纳德，约翰逊成为三周内第四位众议院共和党议长提名人。

;
;

;;相关：;;新任共和党众议院议长迈克·约翰逊是谁？;

;
;

;内部消息约翰逊获得提名后进行的唱名投票显示，尽管一些共和党人缺席，但没有人反对他的议长竞选。在全院投票前的几个小时内，几名反对之前议长提名人的众议院共和党人表示，他们将支持约翰逊，为他的胜利铺平道路。

;

;约翰逊的当选结束了早些时候开始的僵局本月，八名众议院共和党议员与民主党一起罢免加州前议长凯文·麦卡锡。此后的几周内，另外三名议长提名人——路易斯安那州的史蒂夫·斯卡利斯、俄亥俄州的吉姆·乔丹和埃默——曾试图团结共和党会议，但未能成功。

;

;没有议长就位，众议院就一直处于混乱之中。无法推进任何立法。 Biden has called on Congress to pass an aid package to assist America's allies such as Ukraine and Israel, but the House could not take up such a bill until a new speaker was elected. Johnson said on Wednesday that the first measure taken up under his speakership would be a resolution expressing support for Israel amid its war against Hamas.

;

;Although Johnson's election will allow the House to resume business, Democrats have made clear that they will use the new speaker's political record against vulnerable Republicans in the elections next year.

;

;Johnson has ;already faced questions; over his history of supporting Trump's efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election. Johnson, who practiced constitutional law before entering politics, ;was the architect; of a questionable legal argument that offered air cover to House Republicans who wanted to sign an amicus brief urging the US supreme court to throw out the electoral votes of key battleground states won by Biden. More than 100 House Republicans signed on to the amicus brief, but the supreme court ultimately threw out the underlying lawsuit challenging the election results.

;

;Democrats believe Johnson's central role in refuting the 2020 election results and his conservative views on many social issues could help them win back the House next year. Some Democrats were heard saying “bye bye” as House Republicans representing battleground districts, such as Mike Lawler of New York, cast their votes for Johnson.

;

;Delivering remarks after Johnson's election, Jeffries pledged Democrats would “protect the peaceful transfer of power” and “continue to push back against extremism in this chamber and throughout the country”, while simultaneously promising to seek bipartisanship whenever possible.

;

;“The time for partisanship is over. It's time to get back to doing the business of the American people,” Jeffries said. He then reminded Republicans: “Joe Biden won the 2020 presidential election. He's doing a great job under difficult circumstances, and no amount of election denialism will ever change that reality – not now, not ever.”

;

;Speaking after Jeffries, Johnson similarly pledged to work with Democrats on points of mutual interest, while acknowledging their starkly different policy preferences.

;

;“I do look forward to working with you on behalf of the American people,” Johnson told Jeffries. “I know we see things from very different points of view. But I know that in your heart, you love and care about this country and you want to do what's right, and so we're going to find common ground there.”

;

;Even though the House is now open, Johnson's challenges in uniting his deeply divided conference may be just beginning. Government funding is set to expire in less than a month, and Johnson risks causing a federal shutdown unless he can convince fellow Republicans to back a stopgap funding measure. That same dilemma caused the downfall of the last Republican speaker.

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 05:22:01 +0800 Javier Milei endorsed by defeated rival who once sued him for defamationhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/25/argentina-presidential-election-patricia-bullrich-endorse-javier-milei

;
;;Patricia Bulrich speaks with her running mate, Luis Petri, at a press conference to explain the reasons why she supports Javier Milei in the second round of Argentina's election.
;

;The defeated Argentinian presidential candidate Patricia Bullrich, who came third in Sunday's election, has endorsed the libertarian firebrand Javier Milei for next month's runoff vote.

;

;Bullrich took 23.8% of the vote in the first round, finishing third behind ;the surprise frontrunner – the economy minister, Sergio Massa, who won 36.7%; – and Milei who took just over 30%.

;

;“The country needs a fundamental change,” Bullrich said on Wednesday, warning against a “continuation of the worst government in history” – a reference to Massa's Unión por la Patria alliance, led by the former president and current vice-president ;Cristina Fernández de Kirchner.;

;
;

;;Related: ;;Argentina 'puts a limit on madness' as resurgent Peronists stall Milei's rise;

;
;

;Fernández de Kirchner has been in office as either president or vice-president for 12 of the last 20 years and her now-deceased husband Néstor Kirchner was president before her in 2003-2007.

;

;“The urgency of the moment forces us not to be neutral,” Bullrich told reporters. “Argentina cannot start a new Kirchnerist cycle headed by Sergio Massa.”

;

;Bullrich's comments came as her alliance Juntos por el Cambio (Together for Change) split into its three constituent parts. While the former security minister pledged to set aside her “differences” with Milei, Elisa Carrió, of the Civic Coalition party, said she remained horrified by Milei's policy positions, including the legalization of the organ trade, potentially the ;sale of children; and the dollarization of Argentina's economy, which Carrió has warned would open the country's financial markets to drug cartels.
;
; “We are not going to jump into the void to sell organs, because it violates human rights, we do not agree with the sale of children and the legalization of drug trafficking, all of this is going to lead to crimes against humanity,” said Carrió.
;
; A third part of the alliance, the centrist Radical party also declared itself against Milei.

;

;“Voters should be given freedom of action for people to define their choice,” said the Radical senator Luis Naidenoff.
; If Milei can add the 24% of votes obtained by Bullrich on Sunday to his own 30% he will have enough to defeat Massa.

;

;But Massa is hoping to steal votes from both Bullrich and Milei from supporters disenchanted with their alliance.

;

;Bullrich hails from a patrician family and has held cabinet posts and legislative seats in various governments, representing the very political establishment Milei had vowed to extirpate. It is also doubtful if Bullrich's conservative supporters can stomach the unorthodox Milei.

;

;But such political malleability comes naturally to the 67-year-old politician whose first step into politics was as a teenage member of the leftwing Montoneros guerrilla group. Bullrich has at different times represented the Peronist party, the centrist Radicals and various conservative alliances.
;
; During the 2023 election campaign Milei dragged up her guerrilla past, accusing Bullrich of “planting bombs in kindergartens”. Bullrich responded by suing for defamation.

;

;Asked at Wednesday's press conference about the confrontation, Bullrich said she had “forgiven” Milei and was dropping legal charges. Milei for his part claimed that what he had meant to say was that “she threw a bomb in a garden where there was a child”.

;

;A poll published on Wednesday by the anti-Kirchner daily Clarín showed Massa and Milei running neck-and-neck in the runoff, with Milei at 41.6% and Massa at 40.4%, with a 2.4-point margin of error.

;

;The November runoff could be marked by strong absenteeism, with 10.4% saying they would not vote and 7.5% undecided.

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 04:22:02 +0800 Daniel Radcliffe produces film about his paralysed Harry Potter stunt doublehttps://www.theguardian.com/film/2023/oct/25/daniel-radcliffe-produces-film-about-his-paralysed-harry-potter-stunt-double-david-holmes

;
;;Daniel Radcliffe in a scene from Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1.
;

;Daniel Radcliffe has teamed up with his Harry Potter stunt double, who became paralysed after an on-set accident, for an HBO documentary.

;

;David Holmes worked closely with Radcliffe on the Harry Potter films until he sustained a spinal injury during filming for The Deathly Hallows: Part 1 in January 2009. The gymnast from Essex, who was selected to play Radcliffe's double in the first film, broke his neck and was paralysed from the chest down.

;

;The forthcoming documentary, titled David Holmes: The Boy Who Lived, is executive produced by Radcliffe and debuts in November. It will feature candid personal footage shot over the last decade, behind-the-scenes material from Holmes's stunt work, scenes of his current life and intimate interviews with Holmes, Radcliffe, and others.

;

;“The film is a coming-of-age story of stuntman David Holmes, a prodigious teenage gymnast from Essex, England, who is selected to play Daniel Radcliffe's stunt double in the first 'Harry Potter' film, when Daniel is just 11,” the official synopsis from HBO said.

;

;“Over the next 10 years, the two form an inextricable bond, but on the penultimate film a tragic accident on set leaves David paralysed with a debilitating spinal injury, turning his world upside down. As Daniel and his closest stunt colleagues rally to support David and his family in their moment of need, it is David's extraordinary spirit of resilience that becomes their greatest source of strength and inspiration.”

;

;HBO said the film, which is directed by British filmmaker Dan Hartley, reflects universal themes of living with adversity, growing up and forging identities in an uncertain world.

;

;Holmes, who is now 42, has previously revealed details of his tragic accident, which occurred during a flying scene at Warner Bros Studios in Leavesden.

;

;In an interview with the Mirror in 2014, he said he was pulled backwards “at speed” by a high-strength wire in a “jerk back” stunt that replicates the effects of an explosion. However, Holmes was launched into a wall and immediately broke his neck.

;

;He has said the new HBO documentary tells the story of not just his achievements in front of the camera, “but also the challenges I face every day, and my overall attitude to life after suffering a broken neck.

;

;“In the turbulent world we find ourselves living in right now, I would like to quote Harry: 'We are only as strong as we are united, as weak as we are divided.'”

;

;Holmes also thanked medical staff, Radcliffe and the Harry Potter author, JK Rowling, for their support. Writing about Radcliffe, he said they were both “immensely proud of our time on the Harry Potter films, and the joy and comfort it brings to audiences around the world on a daily basis.”.

;

;It is not the first time Radcliffe and Holmes have collaborated since the Harry Potter films – in 2020 the pair joined forces to launch Holmes' Cunning Stunts podcast, which features interviews with other stunt performers across Hollywood.

;

;“I think there's a myth around stuntmen that they are just superhuman in some way,” Radcliffe said of the podcast at the time. “When the public see something really painful or horrible, they think it was a visual effect or that there's some clever, safe way of doing it. Often that's not the case.

;

;“There's no way of faking, for example, falling down stairs.当你被汽车撞到时，你仍然会被汽车撞到，即使它的速度比原来慢。 They find the safest way of doing it, but it can still hurt.”

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 03:22:01 +0800 Roosters may be able to recognise their reflection, study findshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/25/roosters-recognise-reflection-study
;;2023-10-25T18:00:12Z;
;
;;A rooster crows
;

;With their colourful plumage and prominent combs, roosters might be forgiven for sneaking the odd glance in the mirror – particular as research now suggests the birds may be able to recognise their own reflection.

;

;The ability to recognise oneself in the mirror has so far been found in a handful of animals, ;including elephants;, dolphins, great apes and certain fish and birds.

;

;Sonja Hillemacher, one of the authors of the study at the University of Bonn, said animals that can recognise themselves in a mirror often seemed to have more advanced cognitive abilities, and that there was a link to social and emotional intelligence, as well as self-awareness.

;

;“This ability is a fundamental aspect of consciousness. It is also fundamental for us,” she said.

;

;“Our results suggest a level of consciousness [in chickens] that prompts discussions about animal rights and welfare.”

;

;;Writing in the journal Plos One,; Hillemacher and colleagues note that roosters tend to call out to their peers should they see an aerial threat, such as a bird of prey. If a rooster is alone, however, it does not usually raise the alarm as it could draw the predator's attention.

;

;In their first set of experiments, the team placed a rooster in one of two sections of an indoor space. In the other section they placed either a mirror, another rooster, or left it empty.

;

;The team then projected the silhouette of a flying hawk on to the ceiling of the section containing the first rooster.

;

;The results from 58 roosters revealed the birds made far more alarm calls when another rooster was visible to them, with 1.33 alarm calls per bird on average over three tests, than when alone (0.29 calls on average) or faced with the mirror (0.43 calls on average). The team found a similar reduction in calls when they placed a second rooster out of sight behind the mirror.

;

;The team say the findings suggest the birds did not regard their reflection as another rooster, even when accompanied by the smell and sound of a second bird. While that may suggest roosters can recognise themselves in a mirror, the team say there is another possibility.

;

;“It's equally feasible that they regarded their reflection as an odd [member of their species] mimicking their every move, leading them not to emit an alarm call out of irritation,” said Hillemacher.

;

;The researchers also used a traditional “mark test” to probe mirror self-recognition. In those experiments, 18 roosters had either pink or transparent powder dabbed just below their beak, on their chest – a place they cannot usually see. The birds' reactions were then recorded in the presence and absence of a mirror to explore if they saw and understood the mark was on their body – a revelation typically gauged by an animal's tendency to investigate the patch.

;

;The results revealed that while the birds touched and groomed themselves, their behaviour did not differ when a mirror was present, or if the mark was pink or transparent.

;

;The team say that their results suggest mirror tests should be modified to take into account the natural context of the animal being studied.

;

;They also note that with chickens possibly one of the least expected candidates for recognising their own reflection, the results have important implications.

;

;“If roosters can differentiate between their own reflection and the sight of a conspecific, it is likely that this cognitive ability is much more widespread than previously assumed,” the team write.

; Thu, 26 Oct 2023 03:22:01 +0800 Most banned books in US prisons include Amy Schumer and Art of Warhttps://www.theguardian.com/books/2023/oct/25/most-banned-books-list-us-prisons

;
;;Amy Schumer's memoir was flagged by Florida officials for graphic sexual content and for being 'a threat to the security, order, or rehabilitative objectives'.
;

;The literary advocacy group PEN America has released a list of the most banned or restricted books in the US prison system, and the rundown comes with some unexpected entries.

;

;The list includes Amy Schumer's memoir The Girl with the Lower Back Tattoo, flagged by Florida officials for graphic sexual content and for being “a threat to the security, order, or rehabilitative objectives; Sun Tzu's The Art of War; Barrington Barber's Anyone Can Draw: Create Sensational Artwork in Easy Steps; and Prison Ramen: Recipes and Stories from Behind Bars, which comes in as the most banned book.

;

;The banned books list, released Wednesday to coincide with ;Prison Banned Books Week;, comes amid an increase in type of books being banned from the prison system, the group said in a statement.

;

;“The common concept underpinning the censorship we're seeing is that certain ideas and information are a threat,” said the report's lead author, Moira Marquis, senior manager in the prison and justice writing department at PEN.

;

;Marquis told the Associated Press that the most common reason for books being held back is security and sexual content. But that those terms are used loosely and include, in Michigan, Leonard's thriller Cuba Libre and Frederick Forsyth's The Day of the Jackal both listed as a “threat to the order/security of institution”.

;

;A spokesman for the Michigan department of corrections told the wire service that both titles were being re-considered by a new review committee.

;

;PEN says it has found a conjunction between prison and library book bans. The group ;estimates; that more than 40% of all prison book bans took place in Florida last year, amounting to 22,000 books. Texas has more than 10,000 on its banned-from-prison list. ;Florida and Texas also head the list of states; with the largest number of books banned from non-correctional public institutions.

;

;The group says books banned from prisons are larger in number and go beyond questions of content, often requiring them to be sent from “approved vendors”, restrictions designed to stop books being used asa conduit for drugs. PEN calls such reasoning “spurious”.

;

;“We are witnessing vast amounts of time, effort and money expended in order to stop people from reading,” the group says. “This censorship must end.”
